feed.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System

entry.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: In a recent discussion, the concept of front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace was brought up. Front-running refers to entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a transaction that will influence the price of the underlying security. In the context of Bitcoin/Civkit, this could be a board discovering market offers and entering into the trade before publishing the offer on its board.The discussion revolves around Mary the Maker, Terry the Taker, and Bob the bulletin board operator. Mary publishes a limit order to buy a derivative, and Bob has the option to execute against Mary's order. If Bob doesn't want to execute, he relays the order to Terry (and other subscribers to the market). Terry then has the option to execute the trade against Mary's order, and if Terry decides not to execute, Mary's order sits on the bulletin board.The concern raised is that this model resembles more of a brokerage than an exchange market structure. It is suggested that Terry should open his own brokerage and compete on quoting prices with Bob. By comparing metrics like execution quality, Bob and Terry can attract more market activity by providing better prices.Front-running is seen as a positive sign because it indicates active participants and liquidity in the market. The focus should be on identifying products people are interested in trading and providing a good user experience. Other security paradigms are discussed, such as duplicating the announcement of offers to independent boards and monitoring latency anomalies, as well as running the bulletin boards as a federation under Honey Badger BFT.The design of CivKit aims to provide a flexible framework for peer-to-peer marketplaces, where parameters like propagation latency monitoring and federation set and rules can be adjusted to adapt to different types of trades and market participants' tolerance. The goal is to create a censorship-resistant and permissionless global trading system while maintaining confidentiality for market participants. Reputation scoring and incentive frameworks are proposed to ensure efficient and trustworthy operation of the marketplace.Overall, the discussion highlights the challenges and considerations in creating a secure and efficient peer-to-peer marketplace while addressing front-running risks and providing a good user experience.The authors express their gratitude to the peer reviewers and provide an overview of their system architecture. They mention that they will be releasing code and modules gradually, building on top of the Lightning Dev Kit and Nostr libraries. They emphasize their commitment to adhering to the Bitcoin open-source and decentralized standards established by Bitcoin Core. They also express their eagerness to collaborate with the community in order to standardize libraries and ensure interoperability between clients in the long term.The authors welcome feedback on their work and provide links for further exploration. These include a link to the paper, which delves into the architecture of the system, a link to the W3C Recommendation for the DID (Decentralized Identifier) Core specification, a link to the Privacypass website, a link to the GitHub repository containing the paper, and a link to the Lightning Dev Kit website.In conclusion, the message emphasizes the authors' intention to collaborate with the community, adhere to established standards, and seek feedback and improvement. The provided links serve as additional resources for readers interested in exploring the topics discussed further.
